title: Evolutionary Discounting
text:
Time preferences describe an individualâ€™s willingness to wait for a delayed reward. Time preferences are quantitatively described by a discounting function \(\Delta\): a reward of magnitude \(F\) received after delay \(t\) is of the same perceived value as an immediate reward with magnitude:
\[ \text{Present Value} = \Delta(t) \cdot F.\]
Theorists like to use the exponential discounting function \(\Delta_{\text{exp}}(t) = e^{-rt}\), where \(r>0\). Experimentalists find observed time preferences are better explained by non-exponential discounting functions, including the hyperbolic \(\Delta_{\text{hyp}}(t) = \frac{1}{1 + ht}\), where \(h>0\).
\(\textit{For example...}\)
Given the choice between chocolate cake and fruit salad, one evaluates the desserts as follows: - Chocolate cake: benefit of magnitude 1 upon consumption. - Fruit salad: benefit of magnitude 2, received 10 days after consumption.
A decision-maker with hyperbolic discounting function \(\Delta(t) = \frac{1}{1 + t/5}\) prefers chocolate cake if consumption is immediate, and prefers fruit salad if consumption is more than 5 days in the future.
Chocolate cake offers immediate satisfication, whereas fruit salad gives more delayed health benefits. Experiments with human participants find imposing a delay before consumption changes preferences substantially: a common delay before both the small/immediate reward and the larger/delayed increases the likelihood of waiting for the delayed reward.
